body.p: Which of the following represents the probability that a randomly chosen female has pierced ears? In other words, what is the conditional probability that a randomly chosen student has pierced ears, given that this student is female?

response.feedback: Incorrect. P(E | M) represents the probability that a randomly chosen student has pierced ears (E) given that this student is a male (M).
Incorrect. P(not E | M) represents the probability that a randomly chosen student does not have pierced ears (not E), given that this student is a male (M).
Incorrect. P(not M | E) represents the probability that a randomly chosen student is a female (not M) given that this student has pierced ears (E).
Good job! P(E | not M) represents the probability that a randomly chosen student has pierced ears (E) given that this student is a female (not M).

body.p: Which of the following represents the probability that a randomly chosen student is a non-pierced male?

response.feedback: Incorrect. P(not E | M) represents the probability that a randomly chosen student does not have pierced ears, given that the student is a male. Note that we are not looking for a conditional probability here. We are looking for the probability that a randomly chosen student is a non-pierced male.

Incorrect. P(E | not M) represents the probability that a randomly chosen student has pierced ears, given that the student is a female. Note that we are not looking for a conditional probability here. We are looking for the probability that a randomly chosen student is a non-pierced male.
Good job! Indeed, we are not looking for a conditional probability here. We are looking for the probability that a randomly chosen student is a non-pierced male.

Incorrect. While you are right that we are not looking for conditional probability here, P(E and not M) represents the probability that a randomly chosen student is a pierced female, and we are looking for the probability that a randomly chosen student is a non-pierced male.

body.p: P(not E | not M) represents the probability that:

multiple_choice.choice: a randomly chosen male does not have pierced ears.
a randomly chosen female does not have pierced ears.
a randomly chosen student is a non-pierced female.
a randomly chosen non-pierced student is a female.

response.feedback: Incorrect. P(not E | not M) is a probability conditioned on the student selected being a female (not M).
Good job! P(not E | not M) conditions on the student being a female (not M). In other words, we choose only among the female students.

Incorrect. The probability that you chose is P(not E and not M). Note that in P(not E | not M) we are conditioning on the student being a female. In other words, we choose only among the female students.

Incorrect. The probability that you chose assumes that we are choosing only among the non-pierced students, so it represents P(not M | not E), and not the probability we are looking for, which is P(not E | not M).

body.p: What is P(not E | not M), the probability that a randomly chosen female does not have pierced ears?

response.feedback: Incorrect. Your denominator is right. We are conditioning on the student being a female, and therefore restricting ourselves only to the 320 female students. However, note that 288 out of the females are pierced and we are looking for P(not E | not M).

Incorrect. If your denominator is 176, this means that you restrict yourselves to the second column, or, in other words, you condition on the fact that the student is not pierced (not E). 32/176, then, represents P(not M | not E), and we are looking for P(not E | not M).
Good job! When we condition on "not M," this means that we are restricting ourselves to only the 320 female students. Indeed, among them, 32 are not pierced, and therefore 32/320 is the right answer.

Incorrect. If your denominator is 500, this means that you are choosing among the 500 students, without assuming (or conditioning on) anything. 32/500 represents, then, the probability that a randomly chosen student is a non-pierced female—P(not E and not M). Note that we are looking for P(not E | not M)—we are conditioning on the student being a female, or in other words, we are choosing only from the 320 females.
